**NOTE: This blog post cannot be discussed outside of 18F for the time being. If you have questions about this, please contact Dave or Mel. It likely needs to be posted on Tuesday.** 

## Audience

vendor community, federal government.


## Goal of blog post

In June, we released an [RFQ for the Agile Delivery BPA](https://github.com/18F/ads-bpa/blob/18f-pages/assets/ADS%20RFQ%20Revised%20Modification%205.pdf). This upcoming week, the awards will be made and we will be announcing the vendors who have been selected for the Agile BPA and saying 'we're now open for business.'


## Imagery ideas


## Description

An interview with Dave, Chris, and Kathryn about the Agile BPA process, the selection process, and why this is incredibly important. 

@jtag - you have questions you'd like me to ask?

## Who needs to clear the post as a checklist:

- [ ] @vzvenyach, @cscairns 
-  [ ] @OriHoffer (From GSA's Office of Communications and Marketing)
-  [ ] Gia (From GSA's Office of Congressional and Intergovernmental Affairs)
-  [ ] Teressa (From GSA's Office of Communications and Marketing)
-  [ ] @NoahKunin
- [ ] @quepol 

## Expected Publish Date: 8/25
title: Agile BPA interview with Dave, Chris, Kathryn

body:
## Audience
Designers and developers either in or outside of government who are looking to better understand the process in which to design, develop and test new features on their websites and applications.

## Goal of blog post
To outline the process in which this particular project approached building out a new feature and make it accessible.

## Imagery ideas
- Original image of the visual design and layout
- Embedded Codepen doc with finalized toggle, located here: http://codepen.io/juliaelman/pen/eNegVo

## Description
This post will outline the how we approach accessibility in the designs and recommendations on how others may want to work. It will help answer questions like:

- What tools are available for testing for various types of accessibility?
- How do you test for accessibility in the visual design phase of the project?
- What types of elements should you take into consideration when creating accessible forms?

Draft started here: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1HAgVakZHBeZ7eOcdLrc-9yEvNR6yVEigRfWkw3R8cvs/edit

## Who needs to clear the post as a checklist:

-  [ ] @nickbristow @mkhandekar @juliaelman
-  [ ] @OriHoffer (From GSA's Office of Communications and Marketing)
-  [ ] Gia (From GSA's Office of Congressional and Intergovernmental Affairs)
-  [ ] Teressa (From GSA's Office of Communications and Marketing)
-  [ ] @NoahKunin
title: Designing for Accessibility

body:
## Audience
Designers and developers either in or outside of government who are looking for tested and accessible web design patterns to build websites and applications with.

## Goal of blog post
The goal of the post is to be the initial announcement of the USFWDS (soft launch September 14th; hard launch September 16th).

## Imagery ideas
- Various screenshots from different phases of the project (e.g. UX wireframes paired with front end buidl out)
- Animated gifs showing interactive behaviors from the patterns (that coincide with the copy).

## Description
A storytelling post in which the team describes the history, process and challenges of creating an MVP version of the U.S. Federal Web Design Standards. The writing will include notes on collaboration, UX research methods and outcomes, front end decision making (BEM vs. SMACSS) and the purpose/meaning behind building these standards.

Github repo here: https://github.com/18F/usfwds
Project files here: https://drive.google.com/drive/folders/0B_NVRFrsefnvfnhYTkw0ZWpkSjFzQzhCQkt0azFaa05QVFkwNnJFS3AwQjcwWUdZT1ZSRVk

## Who needs to clear the post as a checklist:

-  [ ] #usfwds team
- [ ] @OriHoffer (From GSA's Office of Communications and Marketing)
- [ ] Gia (From GSA's Office of Congressional and Intergovernmental Affairs)
- [ ] Teressa (From GSA's Office of Communications and Marketing)
- [ ] @NoahKunin
title: Introducing the U.S. Federal Web Design Standards library

body:
## Audience
People who manage static sites, especially complicated ones

## Goal of the post
Explain how we built a gem to help us test jekyll frontmatter for errors

## Imagery ideas
I'm bad at this part...
- A broken image
- A post without authors
- The Travis CI status icon for 18f-site (we should add that to the readme, btw)
- A better idea someone else has

## Description
About a year ago we converted this site to run fully on Jekyll and migrated our blog in from Tumblr. When we did that we gained was some freedom and the ability to have our content editable on GitHub. We’ve received quite a few pull requests from our readers to fix our typos and optimize our images. As our blog got more complicated, we started making mistakes that were hard to catch before publishing. As of today, we’ve found a way to catch many (maybe all) of those errors, before they end up in your browser.

## Who needs to clear
- [ ] @NoahKunin 
- [ ] @OriHoffer 
- [ ] OCIA/Gia

We should also wait until we're actually _doing_ this testing on 18f.gsa.gov before bragging about doing it. Making that happen is as easy as merging 18f/18f.gsa.gov#1059 and 18f/18f.gsa.gov#927. Also, I should write some unit tests for the gem.

Draft: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1euA2ovWytWd0zcwy6cmTB2ebEeca5p6Z13mbo7FtR5A/edit
title: How we test 18f.gsa.gov

body:
We haven't talked about it yet on the blog, despite it being public on GitHub, content in other places around the site being updated, and despite the fact we're talking about it across government (CIO Council for example) so we gotta get it out there stat.

Since no one has taken this on, I'm stepping in so I can unblock other things I need to write. 

## Draft link
https://docs.google.com/document/d/1nGOVC-r046EWBgB2M5DOx2yjgnAtLKTjjENVMZfJ9oc/edit

## Audience
So everyone can understand why 18F exists.

## Goal of blog post
We changed a lot of our copy about who we are without explaining why or being transparent about the change outside of those with an ability to read git commits. We should explain this.

1) Explain 18F's vision for the future, so people come to us with the right projects at the right time. 
2) Explain why 18F will focus on culture change as the prime mover / method by which we get to the future.
3) Set up the framework to talk about our 4 new priorities in a subsequent post
4) Set up talking about our core values, what we're not, etc.
5) Set up creating an About page that simply and beautifully wraps all of this into a single piece of content

## Imagery ideas
TBD

## Description
TBD

## Who needs to clear the post as a checklist:

- [x] @NoahKunin
- [ ] @quepol 
- [ ] @aaronsnow 
- [ ] @OriHoffer
- [ ] Gia

TBD
## Description 

Technical debt is a financial metaphor that software developers use to communicate with management the costs associated with a system that is poorly designed and coded. Recent studies suggest that an average technical debt of $3.61 exists per line of software code, or an average of $1.08M per system.

body:
While working on the Ed project, @ultrasaurus and I came across some super useful tools and tricks for working with CSV (comma-separated value) data files. A couple of discussion points, from roughly most general to most specific:

* The awesome [CSVKit] suite of tools for slicing, dicing, summarizing and otherwise munging CSV (and other delimited text) files, and some usage examples.
* Maybe some links to browser-based tools for visualizing CSV data in simple ways?
* "Viewing" and editing CSVs in `vim` using UNIX pipes and tools like [tito].
* Detecting weird character sets (that Microsoft Excel uses by default) and converting CSVs to Unicode (UTF-8) with `iconv`.
* Stripping the [byte order mark] from CSVs.

We should totally use [asciinema].

[CSVKit]: https://csvkit.readthedocs.org/en/
[byte order mark]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Byte_order_mark
[tito]: https://github.com/shawnbot/tito
[asciinema]: https://asciinema.org/
title: CSV tips and tricks

>In 2014, President Obama committed to adopting an open source software policy to support software developed for the Federal government. Open source is publicly available code that does not charge users a purchase or licensing fee for use, modification, or redistribution. Some open source software include terms associated with how the software can be used, but is open to be administered and maintained by a variety entities rather than a single vendor. A government-wide open source policy could cover any number of things, including development of new IT projects, procurement, and in-house development of new apps or tools.

body:
### Audience
Gov Security Types

### Goal of blog post
De-FUD open source software

### Imagery ideas
Sunshine? 

### Description
I hear things like this a lot: "We can't use github because someone might leave their security credentials sitting in the public repo!" Or, as one vendor puts it: "you can't hack what you can't see." We've had some twitter traffic on the topic in the past, too.

We need something we can point to that makes the credible (and IMHO) correct argument that open source is actually _more_ secure than closed source. It should be a longread, that talks about open source up and down the stack, and lines up and knocks down the counterarguments.

It also might be an opportunity to describe how using open source can improve ATO times...

### Who needs to clear the post:
- [ ] Noah

body:
I'm seeing a lot of opportunity to talk about how we're able to do user-centered design, and all that comes with it, in the face of various federal regulations that (maybe) seemingly prohibit these kinds of things.

## Audience:
Other government designers, developers, and agencies looking to hire technical teams

## Goal of post:
Empower the aforementioned audience members to take on work they might not have because they didn't understand regulations.

## Imagery Ideas
- Stack of paperwork (PRA)
- A document in a box behind a bush in a national park (Anti-deficiency)
- The matrix? (Privacy Act)
- Screen shot of the CodeSniffer failing _bad_ on 508 compliance

## Description
A series of posts explaining regulations that affect how we work and what we do to comply with them while remaining agile. Contenders include:
- The Rehabilitation Act (a.k.a. 508, accessibility)
- Paperwork Reduction Act (PRA)
- The Anti-deficiency Act
- The Privacy Act

Thinking we start with 508 since we have a _ton_ of resources to point to there. There's tremendous opportunity to collaborate on these posts with people from CFPB, the DigitalGov team, and USDS teams.

## Who needs to clear?
- [ ] @OriHoffer 
- [ ] Gia
- [ ] Noah

Also tagging the following people who might have words or guidance to contribute to these posts:
- @adelevie 
- @vzvenyach 
- CFPB alums esp. @jpyuda, @vz3, @khandelwal @cmc333333 @theresaanna @jehlers @NoahKunin 
- Current CFPB fellows with expertise in these areas
- @gray might have some contacts in DigitalGov

Will create separate issues for each post and point back to this one as a boilerplate goals/description.

body:
@meiqimichelle, @elainekamlley  any interest in helping draft this post?

## Audience

Front end developers and designers looking for UX research about the single page site trend (see 18f.gsa.gov, useiti.doi.gov, texas.gov, notalone.gov, analytics.usa.gov [among many non-gov websites] for examples).

## Goals of the post

Show what we learned from doing usability research around single pagers that we've built so that others may learn from our work

## Imagery ideas

Screenshot of a single page website "above the fold," likely either 18f.gsa.gov or EITI since we've tested those

## Description

This post will be a summary of the usability research we've done around single pagers. In particular we'd highlight the surprising finding that people do not necessarily know to scroll down the page. This was even discovered observing users who were given an indicator like a bouncing arrow. Single page sites are definitely in vogue right now, and an emerging hypothesis is that the design works for certain types of content. Designers should be careful when considering the single page design and this post will add to a dialog about that decision.

## Who needs to clear

- [ ] @OriHoffer 
- [ ] Gia
- [ ] @NoahKunin 

We'll also consult with other teams at 18F that have done any UX research around these kinds of site.
title: What we've learned about single page sites

body:
I want to challenge a few conceptions people (especially people outside 18F) have about what kind of traffic websites, and government websites in particular, should expect.

To do this, I'd like to share a bunch of traffic stats from our first year -- our 18f.gsa.gov stats, how much traffic various sources tended to share with our work, and stats from our partner projects where we can get their okay.

I want to leave people with the understanding that:

* Just because it's `.gov` doesn't mean people flock to it. Not every government website is a vital mainstream public service.
* What level of traffic to expect for various levels of attention. It's not millions: analytics.usa.gov got 50,000 visits during its successful 2-day launch window. Many media pieces from high-profile institutions didn't seem to deliver a lot of traffic.
* You don't _need_ millions: our most "viral" blog posts netted maybe 10,000 visits. It gets in front of the right people.
* You don't need _thousands_ either: the point of doing this stuff isn't to feel awash in the glory of traffic. It's to make change.
* Having hundreds of people on-site at once should not generally be seen as a strain on resources. If it is, you're probably doing something wrong. 
* The President mentioning your website isn't worth scrambling digital jets for.

There's a lot of blurring and messy ideas above. It's also blurring expectations for blogging vs expectations for services. I think the final product will be more clear, and maybe not all of the above makes it.

(I'll update the issue description with the proper template before getting started, just needed to get his down while it's in my head.)
title: How much web traffic we get and our projects get

body:
Follow-up to the [DATA Act explainer](https://github.com/18F/blog-drafts/issues/162) that showcases a small pilot project that Treasury is running with SBA.

## Background
Cooked this up with Mel Kramer, who suggested that it take the form of someone from comms interviewing the SBA project team. Though 18F has played a pivotal role in this pilot, it's important to lift up the work of others, de-emphasizing 18F, if we're to change culture. And the DATA Act culture is tricky--it's an unfunded piece of work that Congress has demanded of agencies. Agencies don't know what to expect, and there's been little communication to the people on the ground who will need to do the heavy lifting. The message should be: SBA jumped in and started doing this, and you can too.

## Audience
* Anyone interested in DATA Act implementation
* Especially people at federal agencies who will have to do the related data mapping work

## Goal of Blog Post
* Highlight SBA's work as the first agency mapping real data to the new federal spending data standard and share what they learned with other agencies

## Imagery Ideas
A photo of the SBA team would be great but might not be feasible (some are in Denver). I don't think we want anything too data-y or tech-y, since we want to project a non-intimidating image of DATA Act.

## Description
The Small Business Administration is the first agency to undertake the DATA Act. Here's what the team learned and the advice they have for other agencies.
[open to other suggestions]

## Who Needs to Clear this Post
- [ ] Noah
- [ ] Ori
- [ ] Gia
- [ ] Treasury Comms
- [ ] Christina Ho/Renata Maziarz

## Timing
Treasury likes this idea but wants to wait until the pilot is further along (late summer, early fall). Just wanted to seed this idea before I forget!
title: DATA Act SBA Pilot

body:
A couple months back, I sent out a team email about use of (front-end) third party services. It got some good uptake from the team, started an informal audit of our properties led by @msecret -- who also discovered a major privacy leak in the DAP, which [was recently fixed](https://github.com/digital-analytics-program/gov-wide-code/issues/15).

I'm planning to turn this into a blog post, aimed at both website owners and web developers, explaining the issues and what to do about them.

This is different than HTTPS -- blunt, martial policy about third party services isn't practical or feasible. However, consciousness-raising and restraint go a long way, and that's what this post intends to foster.

## Audience

* Web developers, especially front-end developers.
* Privacy advocates and browser makers.
* Fellow federal government website owners who are trying to do their best and keep up with best practices.

## Goal of blog post

Raise awareness among web developers, try to set a different norm for best practices around third parties.

Secondary goals: create some meaningful criteria for when to use third party services, and call on browser makers to consider user-visible indicators around third parties.

## Imagery ideas

Not sure.

## Description

See above.

## Who needs to clear the post:

- [ ] Noah
- [ ] Ori
- [ ] Gia
title: Being careful with third party services

body:
## Audience

- Tech organizations
- Government tech enthusiasts/followers

## Goal of blog post

Introduce the concept of the "grouplet" as an ad-hoc working model for addressing cross-organizational needs. Shed light on pros and cons.

## Imagery ideas

Perhaps the "18F/USDS Rainbow of Death" image from slide 49 of my [Solving the Total Problem... preso](http://goo.gl/5TkS7I).

## Description

From the [Grouplet Playbook intro](https://pages.18f.gov/grouplet-playbook/):

"Grouplets" are self-organizing teams of volunteers that address concerns affecting a broad segment of the organization. 18F currently has two types of Grouplets:

- **Working Groups**: leaders are emergent from the group, and often have no authority and little if any direct resources; it is incumbent upon them to recruit volunteers and make the best use of their time
- **Guilds**: leaders are established by the 18F Leadership team, often have a specific authorities and objectives, and have dedicated staff

This guide aims to provide aspiring Grouplet organizers with a "bag of tricks" for:

- getting a Grouplet organized and productive very quickly,
- for maintaining team cohesion over time,
- for understanding the various forces at play in an organization, and
- for making the entire undertaking both high-impact and fun!

## Who needs to clear the post

- [ ] #180
- [ ] @18F/blog
title: Grouplets

body:
## Audience

- Tech organizations
- Government tech enthusiasts/followers

## Goal of blog post

Introduce our 18F Time policy, analogous to Google's 20% time policy. In other words, the well-articulated policy Google should've had, but never did.

## Imagery ideas

Maybe the "Crossing the Chasm/Rainbow of Death" image from slide 25 of my [Google & the Gov't preso](http://goo.gl/TU2pii), reasoning being that "Instigators" need 20% time to invest in solutions that will ultimately benefit the rest of the population.

## Description

“18F time” is the label given to work that benefits the 18F team as a whole, or its broader mission of improving government, whether or not that work is for a billable project. Borrowed from Google’s famous “20% time”, the intention is to permit 18F team members the latitude to improve team processes and capabilities (e.g. via working groups/guilds/grouplets); to produce blog posts that provide insight into the team, its working models, and its impact; to develop new features that increase value, improve user experience, increase delivery capacity; and to build prototypes that may lead to future inter-agency business.

## Who needs to clear the post

- [ ] #178
- [ ] Team ratification
- [ ] @18f/blog

body:
## Audience

- Tech organizations
- Government tech enthusiasts/followers

## Goal of blog post

Introduce the concept of [Objectives and Key Results](https://pages.18f.gov/grouplet-playbook/processes-and-artifacts/#okrs) (OKRs) and how we apply them at 18F.

## Imagery ideas

https://filmbalaya.files.wordpress.com/2013/01/618_movies_rocky_10.jpg

## Description

The "Objectives and Key Results" process, or "OKRs for short", is a quarterly process for setting goals and reviewing progress. It involves defining roughly three-to-five high-level strategic "Objectives" that support the team's overall mission, and defining a number of "Key Results" that implement each objective and serve to demonstrate measurable progress. Ideally most of these are framed in terms of problems to solve, not specific features to build; this enables grouplet members to devise their own creative solutions.

## Who needs to clear the post

@18f/blog
title: Objectives and Key Results

body:
This could either be a high-level post about designing for lots of different web browsers and platforms, and/or a nerdy post about real-world strategies for front end developers. Or maybe two different posts?

On the design front:
* why supporting old/broken browsers is often necessary, with a nod to [analytics.usa.gov](http://analytics.usa.gov) and a brief discussion of how the DAP program gives us insight into web browser stats for different government sites
* the merits of "inclusive" (as opposed to "responsive") design, and progressive enhancement vs. graceful degradation—not just for old browsers, but for mobile browsers and weird screen sizes
* examples of what we've done; and strategies, references and tools for designers

**Maybe some of this stuff should go in the [frontend guide](https://github.com/18F/frontend-style-guide), and we just link to that instead?** cc @meiqimichelle @msecret @noahmanger @juliaelman 

Development points:
* strategies for progressive enhancement and inclusive/responsive web design
* front end development tools that help with cross-browser compatibility
* manual and automated testing strategies, with links to our [testing cookbook](http://18f.github.io/testing-cookbook/)
title: Cross-browser/platform design and development

This post will also be for anyone who doesn't need an in-depth guide before tackling the [Github tutorial](https://18f.gsa.gov/2015/03/03/how-to-use-github-and-the-terminal-a-guide/) He plans to use already-existing material from [Gray's workshop](https://docs.google.com/a/gsa.gov/document/d/1l-M5fDItLG0NsgmRChItScmbAECRx4KqksNxa3efgzo/edit?usp=sharing) and from the [Hub Participation sprint document](https://hub.18f.us/docsprint/guides/participation/).

Audience:
- New Employees of 18F
- People interested in learning about GitHub

Signoff:

GSA Comms

Visuals: Gifs.

cc: @gboone @gbinal @elainekamlley @jeanninehunter @kategarklavs
title: Basic guide to GitHub

## Audience
Developers

## Goal of blog post
Promoting development practices that ease the adoption of automated testing.

## Imagery ideas
none, aside from code samples

## Description
How to make kinder, gentler API tests by making the computer look for the sorts of things a human would look for, in the order that a human would scan for problems, thus making failures more transparent and greatly easing the test failure debugging process. 

## Who needs to clear the post
- [ ] Ori
- [ ] Gia
- [ ] Noah

## Draft

body:
The list below started from an inquiry by some SF-based data scientists.  I think it would make a good blog post.

## Audience
private data scientists 

## Goal of blog post
open source contributions, use cases for open data, blog posts about open data
broadly:  
* private sector individuals or companies helping the US Gov
* private sector individuals or companies helping each other
* fuel the economy

## Imagery ideas
* some kind of imaginary data viz?

## Description – TBD

## Who needs to clear the post
@ultrasaurus - review to double-check that it has the kind of info that got AirBnB excited

## Draft

### Recreation.gov 
original source @meiqimichelle 
The questions people have been asking previously could not be answered with the old dataset/XML download. Questions like: 'I want to know all campsites available with a 50-mile radius of my current location' -- not sure whether they can be answered with this dataset, but would be great to try.    
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/us-government-apis/XaBc1xvtejM

https://www.govcode.org/ -- code is on github, created by @dlapiduz , if anyone is interested, I'm sure he would be happy to come visit

### Federal contracting
source: @kaitlin 
FBOpen - API for the solicitations - https://fbopen.gsa.gov/  , https://18f.github.io/fbopen/
Spending: http://www.usaspending.gov/data
solicitation ID, data dictionary
Potential questions:
NLP analysis of RFPs that have 0 or 1 or many responses -- what makes a good RFP?  are there "hidden" sole source RFPs pretending to be open?
Are there any patterns in RFPs where resulting contracts consistently go over-budget or are delivered on-time and within budget?

### FOIA
via Gabriel Ramirez
dataset of documents that have been the response to a FOIA request

repositories of responses 
 500 GB+
https://github.com/18F/foia/tree/master/documents
Potential questions:
* what is the language behind specific requests?
* what makes a request successful?  can we separate out requests from experts from people that are new for it?
* unsupervised learning, since we don’t know the data
* split it up into agencies
* maybe cluster analysis, since we don’t know exactly what the thing is we’re looking for

### additionally...
Depending on when this goes live, we could add:
* Gov website analytics (not yet announced)
* FEC API, (not ready yet)
title: how data scientists can help the US government

body:
From the all-team email:

> Our changes, which focus mostly on the pre- and post-drafting processes, are as follows:
>
> * **Editorial Calendar:** When you think of a post you’d like to write, add it to the 18F editorial calendar! Simply create an entry on your ideal publication date and members of the Outreach Team will contact you with more details.
> * **GitHub Process Change:** You no longer need to create GitHub issues for posts you’d like to write: The Outreach Team will create them for you using the information you provide when you add an entry to the editorial calendar. 
> **Weekly Blog Huddle:** Struggling with writer’s block? Want feedback on a first draft? Join our weekly blog huddle, to be held each Tuesday from 11:30 to 12:30 PT/2:30 to 3:30 ET. Greg and Kate will be on hand to answer process questions, review drafts, and discuss blogging in a more general sense. No RSVP necessary, and you don’t need to have scheduled a post to join in – everyone is welcome to join.
> * **Markdown Changes:** No longer will you need to convert your posts to markdown: The Outreach Team will take care of this detail.
title: Update the README with the new new blogging process
